subject: Art & Design
title: The Horror Genre: Why We Love Being Scared
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on The Horror Genre: Why We Love Being Scared.

hook.text: You know the monster is behind the door. The music swells. Your heart races. You love every second.

buildup.text: Horror cinema works by triggering the fight-or-flight response safely. Real fear, zero real danger.

discovery.text: Suspense (knowing something the character doesn't) is scarier than surprise (sudden jump scares).

twist.text: The scariest horror films often show very little. Jaws barely shows the shark. Your imagination fills the gap.

climax.text: Horror reflects societal fears: nuclear anxiety (1950s monsters), technology (modern), pandemics, isolation.

punchline.text: Horror doesn't exploit fear. It helps us rehearse it safely.

quiz.question: Why did Jaws show the shark so rarely?
options: Showing less forces the audience's imagination to create scarier imagery
The mechanical shark kept breaking down (happy accident)
Audiences complained about the shark's appearance
